timeline.message: Add TargetConnectionManager tests
Include hostId parameter in GET reports/recordings

Remove internal WebServer recordings state

Remove recordings and downloadCounts maps to move toward a
non-connection-oriented WebServer

Also remove wait-for-download command, which relied upon downloadCounts
map and was not necessarily useful anyway

WebServer made non-connection-oriented

WebServer API methods consumed by Command implementations no longer
assume any connection state. Commands must specify the connection, if
any. This paves the way for commands which require users to specify the
target as well.
Remove redundant block scope
Apply spotless formatting

Set up "connected" commands to establish their own target connections

Add methods to base classes AbstractConnectedCommand and
AbstractRecordingCommand for establishing new connections to target JVMs
and performing actions using those connections. This allows the commands
to be executed without first requiring state to track the
"active"/current target connection. The ListCommand is modified to
become stateless this way as a first test.

Start all servers in ContainerJFR main

Do not cascade HttpServer startup through WebServer and do not start
MessagingServer in module

All "connected" commands require a target arg

Commands which operate on a target JVM all require a target arg to be
provided, and use a new utility method in their abstract base class to
establish target connections on-demand
Apply spotless formatting

Remove ConnectionListener interface

Remove now-unused ConnectionListener interface, since connect/disconnect
commands no longer exist and the commands and HTTP APIs are
connectionless. Also remove is-connected command, which likewise no
longer makes sense.
Apply spotless and spotbugs fixes

Bump required container-jfr-core version

Make available new JFRConnection + Toolkit API enhancements

Implement TargetConnectionManager

Implement TargetConnectionManager and refactor Commands and WebServer to
use it rather than JFRConnectionToolkit

TargetConnectionManager wraps around the JFRConnectionToolkit and
provides facilities for safely creating, using, and cleaning up
JFRConnections. It also (currently) enforces sequential connections so
that ContainerJFR only establishes a single JMX connection to a single
target at any given time.
Rename API paths from hosts to targets
Re-add target-less HTTP API for saved recordings (only)
Ensure lock is released when reports are generated
Ensure WebServer reports correct HTTP/HTTPS schemes
Use JMX URL for target ID rather than host:port

Rename hostId -> targetId

Only affects internal variable and method naming, but for consistency's
sake, renames hostId to targetId to match API
Add test for commands handling TCM throws
Remove redundant blank string checks
Add "mixin" interface for target ID validation testing
Fix delete-saved argument validation IOOB bug
Add "mixin" interface for recording name validation testing
Add "mixin" interface for event specifier validation testing
Ensure empty strings are tested
Add test for duplicate recording save renaming
Add ScanTargets command tests
Enable connection reuse
Add TargetConnectionManager tests
Add TargetConnectionManager tests
Update COMMANDS.md for new connectionless command channel protocol

timeline.bodyText: Is this new argument to connect methods a list of cleanup functions to invoke? I suppose there will be a corresponding container-jfr-core PR?
timeline.author: ebaron

replies.bodyText: Yes exactly, it's a list of functions to be invoked when the underlying connection is closed. I already went ahead and pushed these additions in container-jfr-core (v0.12.x), since they were relatively trivial - the actual connection close detection and cleanup handling is done by the JMC classes we're using behind the scenes, but -core used to just pass in an empty list of cleanup functions every time.
replies.author: andrewazores

replies.bodyText: Oh cool, thanks for the explanation. I was looking in master for the changes, I see them now in 0.12.3.
replies.author: ebaron
